comments:
This course is an introduction to the theory and practice of database management systems. Topics include the Entity-Relationship approach as a modeling tool, the relational model, algebra, calculus, commercial systems, database design and relational normalization, physical data organization and indexing structures. 

Students found the class very informative and interesting, although “a little too theoretical and not practical enough,” sometimes employing “unnecessary complexity.”

Professor Ives was described as both knowledgeable and a great teacher. Students acknowledged that Ives clearly enjoyed teaching the class, which enhanced their enjoyment of the class.

The final project for this course accounted for the majority of work for the project, although students described this final project as the best part of the course. The problem sets were interesting, and well paced. The work, however, was graded slowly and unreliably. CIT591 or equivalent is a prerequisite for this course.
